title: TerraClimate
description: Global climate and water balance time series.
contents:
Details


This dataset provides monthly climate and climatic water balance variables. TerraClimate uses climatically aided interpolation, combining high-spatial resolution climatological normals from the WorldClim dataset, with coarser resolution time varying (i.e., monthly) data from other sources to produce a monthly dataset of precipitation, temperature, wind speed, vapor pressure, and solar radiation. TerraClimate additionally produces monthly surface water balance datasets using a water balance model that incorporates reference evapotranspiration, precipitation, temperature, and interpolated plant extractable soil water capacity.


Subdatasets

totalPrecipitation | Total precipitation (mm)

description
value_range

title: tidalFlats
description: Global distribution of tidal flats
contents:
Details


This datasets maps tidal flats globally, derived with 707,528 Landsat acquisitions. These acquisitions were classified using Machine learning thorugh Google Earth Engine. The original data is provided at a 30-m resolution and on 5-year epochs. Here, we filled temporal gaps with the nearest year, and aggregated the original masks to into 300-m resolution layers, expressing per-pixel percentages of tidal flats.


Subdatasets

title: BECK_climateMap
description:
Global Koppen-Geiger climate classification at a 1-km resolution for the 
present-day (1980 to 2016) and for projected future conditions (2071 to 2100) 
under climate change
contents:
Details


The present-day map is derived from an ensemble of four high-resolution, topographically-corrected climatic maps. The future map is derived from an ensemble of 32 climate model projections (scenario RCP8.5), by superimposing the projected climate change anomaly on the baseline high-resolution climatic maps. For both time periods we calculate confidence levels from the ensemble spread, providing valuable indications of the reliability of the classifications. The new maps exhibit a higher classification accuracy and substantially more detail than previous maps, particularly in regions with sharp spatial or elevation gradients.

title: CCI_landCover
description:
Global, yearly land cover derived in the context of the 
Climate Change Initiative (CCI), from 1992 to the present
contents:
Details


This data provides information on the spatial and temporal evolution of 22 land cover classes, which have been defined using the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization’s (UN FAO) Land Cover Classification System (LCCS). To produce this dataset, the entire Medium Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (MERIS) Full and Reduced Resolution archive from 2003 to 2012 was first classified into a unique 10-year baseline LC map. This is thenback- and up-dated using change detected from (i) Advanced Very-High-Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) time series from 1992 to 1999, (ii) SPOT-Vegetation (SPOT-VGT) time series from 1998 to 2012 and (iii) PROBA-Vegetation (PROBA-V) and Sentinel-3 OLCI (S3 OLCI) time series from 2013.

title: CCI_landCover_history
description:
Historical maximum extent of generic land cover types derived from the 
CCI land cover dataset
contents:
Details


This dataset provides historical representations of the spatial distribution of generic land cover classes. To derive these data, we thematicaly aggregated the CCI land cover into generic class groups (e.g. agriculture, desertic) on a yearly basis. Then, for each derived layer, we derived a mask with its maximum historical extent. Finally, we resampled the output to a 1-km resolution, depicting per-pixel percentages of the given class group.


Subdatasets

title: CCI_permafrost
description: Time-series of the extent of permafrost in the northern hemisphere
contents:
Details


Permafrost underlies approximately one quarter of the terrestrial Northern Hemisphere. Under the threat of climate change, the warming soils lead permafrost to decrease in extent, affecting the microbial breakdown of organic carbon and the consequent release of greenhouse gases. This dataset allows us to observed the long-term variability of permafrost. Developed in the context of the Climate Change Initiative (CCI), this dataset covers the period of 1997 to 2018 at a 1-km resolution. We resampled this dataset to a 300-m resolution. When the permafrost cover was below 100%, the respective percent cover was divided equaly among the 300-m pixels underlying a 1-km pixel. Additionally, the period of 1992 to 1996 was covered by replicating the 1997 state.


Subdatasets

percentCover | Per-pixel extent of permafrost (%)
content
description
value_range
0…100

title: CCI_SM
description: Global time-series of soil moisture, from 1978 to the present
contents:
Details


This dataset was developed in the context of the Climate Change Initiative (CCI), and maps soil moisture on monthly basis from 1978 to the present. The ESA CCI Soil moisture is a data fusion product, combining inputs from both passive and active satellite sensors. The original data is daily, but we aggregated it on a monthly basis. Here, we derived a monthly weighted average, weighting the time series of soil moisture at each pixel coordinate by the corresponding data quality.

title: CHELSA
description: Global time-series of climate precipitation and temperature.
contents:
Details


CHELSA provides monthly data on precipitation and temperature, derived by downscaling global atmospheric models. The temperature data is based on statistical downscaling of atmospheric temperatures, while the precipitation data incorporates orographic predictors such as wind fields, valley exposition, and boundary layer height, with a subsequent bias correction.

title: GFC
description: Yearly global forest cover percentages
contents:
Details


This dataset extends on Hansen’s Global Forest Change (GFC) data product. The original dataset depicts yearly forest cover changes and overall gains within a given observation period. Here, we combine both data components to derive yearly forest cover data. To the baseline of the GFC, mapped for 2000, we removed percent changes on a yearly basis using the reference year of change. From 2012 to 2019, we additionally added information on gains. The year of 2012 is the first where gains are quantified. For that reason, tree cover percentages from 2001 to 2011 should be handled with care.


Subdatasets

canopyDensity | Tree canopy density (%)
content
description
value_range
e.g. 0…100
percentGain | Increase in tree canopy since the year 2000 (%)

title: GME
description: Global Mountain Maps
contents:
Details


This dataset offers different classifications of mountains following different definitions. The K1 resource used a 1 km DEM which was processed using a combination of elevation, slope and relative relief. Relative relief, or ruggedness, is the difference between maximum and minimum elevation in a moving neighborhood analysis window (NAW) and is computed for every raster cell. The K1 layer defined six classes of mountains, where the upper three classes were defined by elevation ranges. The lower three classes were defined either by a combination of elevation and slope, or elevation and relative relief. The circular NAW for computing the relative relief used a 5 pixel (~7 km) radius for an approximate NAW size of 150 km2. The K2 resource was developed using ruggedness as the determining factor, where any relative relief greater than 200m in the NAW was considered mountainous. The original K2 resource used a 1 km DEM and an approximately 9km2 NAW to determine relative relief and then generalized the relative relief surface to an approximately 4.5 km grid (at the equator). The K3 resource was developed using a finer spatial resolution (250 m) DEM and feature-based extraction algorithms with variable NAW sizes used to extract a set of global Hammond landforms with 16 landform types, of which four were mountain classes. E. H. Hammond was a pioneer of landform mapping and described three parameters for distinguishing different types of plains, hills, mountains, and tablelands. The three classification parameters are slope, relative relief, and profile, where the profile parameter assesses the amount of relatively flat terrain in upland locations to delineate tablelands. The 250 m global Hammond landforms product was based on an automated extraction of classes in a GIS environment, and the K3 mountains product was an export of the four mountain classes into a global mountains datalayer.


Subdatasets

content

4

5

6
1000m > Elev >= 300m & LER > 300m
7
Inner Isolated Areas

content

title: iGFC
description: Forest cover density time-series from 1992 to 2018
contents:
Details


This dataset fuses multiple remote sensing products derived from satellite with different spatial resolutions, such as Landsat, AVHRR, and Spot. This dataset extends on the time-series data from the Global Forest Change (GFC) dataset, which covers the period from 2000 to the present, using a spatially and temporally explicit machine learning algorithm. This method integrates coarse resolution data on vegetation dynamics, data on high and low-resoluton data on change dynamics, and high and mid-resolution data on land cover, to construct a consistent yearly forest density data product from 1992 to 2018 mapped with a 300-m resolution.

description: Typical phenology of deciduous forests derived with PROBA-V data time-series
contents:
Details


This dataset provides information on the average per-pixel phenology of deciduous forests. It maps the Start of Season (SoS), Mid of Season (MoS) and End of Season (EoS), which is through a threshold method applied over a time-series of intra and inter-annual Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). The NDVI time-series was measured with the PROBA-V between 1999 and 2017.

title: LTQA
description: Landsat acquisition quality mapped on a yearly basis
contents:
Details


This dataset provides per-pixel information on the frequency and quality of Landsat acquisitions between 1982 and 2020. For each year, we counted the number of acquisitions and evaluated the intra-annual acqusition quality. The closer the quality metric is in value to the acquisition frequency, the better the quality of the satellite images. In addition, this dataset provides a quality index, which is the quotient between the image quality metric and the acquisition frequency. The closest the output is to 1, the highest the quality of the imagery in the given year.


Subdatasets

frequency | Number of satellite acquisitions per pixel
content
description

e.g. 0…n
quality | Sum of quality weights per pixel

title: MERIT_DEM
description: Multi-Error-Removed Improved-Terrain (MERIT) Digital Elevation Model (DEM)
contents:
Details


MERIT DEM is a high accuracy global DEM with a resolution of 90 m. It combines multiple existing DEM datasets (NASA SRTM3 DEM, JAXA AW3D DEM, Viewfinder Panoramas DEM), making use of their combined strenghts to address their individual weaknesses. The present version of this dataset was aggregated to 300 m. Furthermore, the dataset was combined with GEBCO bathymetry data, which was added to oceanic data gaps in the MERIT DEM.

title: pixelArea
description: Global map of per-pixel areas
contents:
Details


This dataset provides per-pixel estimtes of areas within a WGS84, lat/lon grid. This layer was derived with the Harvesine method, which estimates the distance in meters of a distance between two geographical points. This method was used to estimate the distance between the edges of a pixel, across both latitude and longitude. These distances were then used to estimate the are of the pixel.


Subdatasets

title: soilGrids
description: Gridded soil database (soilGrids)
contents:
Details


This dataset provides global maps of soil properties derived with state-of-the-art machine learning methods. SoilGrids prediction models are fitted using over 230,000 soil profile observations from the WoSIS database and a series of environmental covariates. Covariates were selected from a pool of over 400 environmental layers (e.g. climate, land cover), and originated from different data products derived with Earth observation data. The outputs of SoilGrids are global soil property maps at six standard depth intervals (according to the GlobalSoilMap IUSS working group and its specifications). Prediction uncertainty is quantified by the lower and upper limits of a 90% prediction interval.


Subdatasets
